qas.question: What is the process of making beer called?
What is a building called that is used for making beer?
What is company that makes beer typically known as?
What is beer classified as when it is made for non-commerical consumption?
In what year was home brewing first allowed in the UK?

plausible_answers.text: homebrewing to become a popular hobby

qas.question: The US was the last contry to allow homebrewing in which year?
A commercial building for brewing beer is called what?
Brewing beer is subject to what in all countries?
What country relaxed brewing legislation in 1936?
What country relaxed brewing legislation in 1927?
What country relaxed brewing legislation in 1987?
What became a hobby in the US due to relaxed laws in 1987?

context: The process of making beer is known as <a0_0>brewing<a0_0/>. A dedicated building for the making of beer is called <a1_0>a <b7_0>brewery<b7_0/><a1_0/>, though beer can be made in the home and has been for much of its history. A company that makes beer is called either a brewery or <a2_0>a brewing company<a2_0/>. Beer made on a domestic scale for non-commercial reasons is classified as <a3_0>homebrewing<a3_0/> regardless of where it is made, though most homebrewed beer is made in the home. Brewing beer is subject to <b8_0>legislation and taxation<b8_0/> in developed countries, which from the late 19th century largely restricted brewing to a commercial operation only. However, <b9_0>the UK<b9_0/> government relaxed legislation in <a4_0>1963<a4_0/>, followed by <b10_0>Australia<b10_0/> in 1972 and the <b11_0>US<b11_0/> in <b6_0>1978<b6_0/>, allowing <b5_0><b12_0>homebrewing<b12_0/> to become a popular hobby<b5_0/>.
